songs.full_title: Adventure of a Lifetime by Coldplay
songs.title: Adventure of a Lifetime

description.plain:
The groovy fifth track on Coldplay’s dynamic A Head Full of Dreams takes a step into disco, with a simplistic song about life and love, backed by a funky dance floor beat. It features a prominent guitar riff that was inspired by the riff on Guns N' Roses “Sweet Child O' Mine.”

According to bassist Guy Berryman,

[The track] started as a freeform musical session and was called something else, Legends or something. It had a different chord sequence and different hooks and one-by-one things were taken away and things got added.

songs.full_title: A Head Full of Dreams by Coldplay
songs.title: A Head Full of Dreams

description.plain: The explosive, ecstatic and colorful opening track on Coldplay’s A Head Full of Dreams introduces the listener to the album’s enigmatic world and ever-changing sound. The track, through its blissful electronic rock presentation, led by bass and guitar, and lyrics describing a world where dreams come to life, “A Head Full of Dreams” introduces the album in the wildest way possible.

songs.full_title: A Hopeful Transmission by Coldplay
songs.title: A Hopeful Transmission

description.plain:
As we finally are heading for an ending, A Hopeful Transmission might be a turning point in the story, with an orchestra and some instruments, as well as one sample, for the eleventh track on the modern-day rock opera.



A transmission has just been sent for the rebels, and the entire future, as they know it, is in the hands of them alone. But despite having a fleeting chance, they are outnumbered and outgunned, and is theoretically impossible to win. Meanwhile, Mylo comes back to save the future.

songs.full_title: *✧ (Alien Choir) by Coldplay
songs.title: *✧ (Alien Choir)

description.plain:
“*✧,” or alternatively titled, “Alien Choir,” is the first interlude on Coldplay’s ninth studio LP, Music of the Spheres.

The song was produced and written by former collaborator, Jon Hopkins, who has made multiple appearances on various Coldplay albums, such as Viva la Vida or Death and All His Friends and Ghost Stories.

Jacob Collier also contributes his backing vocals to the song. He also makes an official feature on the sixth track of the album, “Human Heart”.

songs.title: A L I E N S
songs.title_with_featured: A L I E N S

description.plain:
The third track of Coldplay’s 2017 EP Kaleidoscope, “A L I E N S” is a song about refugees fleeing their home from a war-torn planet and trying to seek refuge somewhere else.

The proceeds of this song go to the Migrant Offshore Aid Station, to help save migrants on the Mediterranean Sea.

description.plain: “All I Can Think About Is You” is the opening track of the Kaleidoscope EP, released for download and streaming on July 14 2017, and released on CD and vinyl on August 4 2017. A snippet of the song was teased the day before on social media. The first half of the song is reminiscent of early Coldplay providing a nice throwback for longtime fans.

songs.full_title: All Your Friends by Coldplay
songs.title: All Your Friends

description.plain:
All Your Friends is a dedication by the band to all of those who fought in WWI and a portrayal of the traumatic experiences and ordeals that people had to go through. The music video was released a few days before Remembrance Day in 2014, with a small message at the end:

In memory of all those from all nations who fought in the First World War.

songs.full_title: Always in My Head by Coldplay
songs.title: Always in My Head

description.plain:
The opening track on Coldplay’s largely-anticipated sixth studio album, Ghost Stories; a haunting, ambient teardrop follow up to the band’s technicolour rock opera explosion, 2011’s Mylo Xyloto.

The song introduces the basic narrative and the two characters of Ghost Stories; a man, whose point of view is represented in this album, and a woman who he loved very much but had broken away from him.

songs.full_title: Amazing Day by Coldplay
songs.title: Amazing Day

description.plain:
The ninth track on Coldplay’s love letter to life, A Head Full of Dreams, “Amazing Day” takes the reminiscing upon love and life to the stars, in a song that celebrates the “beautiful, crazy design” of the world around the singer and his significant other.

songs.full_title: A Message by Coldplay
songs.title: A Message

description.plain:
“A Message” is a love song and the eighth track of Coldplay’s X&Y. The lyrics and melody were inspired by John Ireland’s 1664 hymn “My Song Is Love Unknown,” which is also Chris Martin’s favorite hymn.

Around the time that Coldplay was recording X&Y, Chris Martin’s father-in-law passed away. “A Message” may have been written for his wife Gwyneth Paltrow, who reportedly (and understandably) went into a depression after her father’s death (Martin supposedly wrote “Fix You” as a way of cheering her up).

songs.full_title: Another's Arms by Coldplay
songs.title: Another’s Arms

description.plain:
The morbid sixth track on Coldplay’s sixth studio album, Ghost Stories, sees the man at the centre of the story go deeper into his emotions. While he tries to forget about the woman he no longer has, he starts to reminisce about the times the two had together instead.

The track was one of the few songs from Ghost Stories to have been teased before the album’s release, as it was performed alongside “Always in My Head” in the run-up to the release day.

songs.full_title: Arabesque by Coldplay
songs.title: Arabesque

description.plain:
The co-lead single “Arabesque” (which is the lead single for the Sunrise part of the album) is Coldplay’s way of trying to sew peace in the wake of the western fear of Islam with the war on terrorism going on. Instrumentally, the song merges western musical styles with Middle Eastern rhythms (like with the guitar & saxophone) placing the idea that “music unites us all”.

Arabesque is a visual art genre, which was mostly used in Islamic countries. For example, in architecture, it’s an ornamental design consisting of intertwined flowing lines, originally found in ancient Islamic art. While in dance and ballet, it is a dancing posture. The name of the songs is very apropos to the whole theme of the album being Arabic and bringing the culture to western media. The meaning of the track is also parallel and similar to the song “بنی آدم (Son of Adam)” by the Persian poet, Sadi.

songs.full_title: A Rush of Blood to the Head by Coldplay
songs.title: A Rush of Blood to the Head
songs.title_with_featured: A Rush of Blood to the Head

description.plain:
The title track of “A Rush of Blood to the Head” deals with revenge and loss of emotional control we experience within it.

Furthermore, the British band tackle once again emotional intelligence and the ability to be conscious of our feelings and emotions. The protagonist is suffering from impulsive behaviour and he’s regretting his thoughtless actions, but blaming it upon what he calls “A rush of blood to the head.” The truth is he’s lost and unaware of how he feels.

songs.full_title: A Sky Full of Stars by Coldplay
songs.title: A Sky Full of Stars

description.plain:
One of Coldplay’s most hyped tracks ever, described by attendees of Coldplay’s secret Ghost Stories shows as “wonderfully produced” and “upbeat, happy, makes you want to stand up and dance,” “A Sky Full of Stars” is the centerpiece of Ghost Stories, bringing the emotional treadmill to an explosive climax.

The track was released as Coldplay’s second single from Ghost Stories, after “Magic,” with the track premiering on 29 April 2014.

EDM artist Avicii was a primary producer on the track and Chris Martin later revealed in an interview that he asked the producer to play the piano parts.

songs.full_title: A Whisper by Coldplay
songs.title: A Whisper

description.plain:
“A Whisper” serves as the continuation of the themes of an existential crisis, which can only be cured by finding love and someone to share life with.

From another point of view, the song is dealing with paranoia in a relationship, known as “A Whisper” in the head of the protagonist.

songs.full_title: Bigger Stronger by Coldplay
songs.title: Bigger Stronger

description.plain:
1st song on Safety EP, May 1998 and The Blue Room EP, October 1999.

This song sarcastically represents the insatiable desire of humans to continually create and have bigger, better things, ways of doing things, and overall lifestyles, even when these such things are already at a reasonable standard.

An interesting observation involving this song and the EP’s closer, “Such A Rush”, is that they both touch on the idea of humans constantly pursuing materialistic lifestyles, but this song does so through the sarcastic view of the narrator themself wishing to have a better life, while “Such A Rush” explicitly mentions the money-centric desires of humans to the audience. This is a particular way to address an issue in the sequencing of albums, where both the opening and closing tracks make reference to the same idea/s, and in this case, the message is portrayed in different ways to deliver a message.

songs.title: Biutyful

description.plain:
The song is all about the universal love among humans. Our ability to be obsessed due to love is in my opinion one of the things that make us humans so special in the universe.

The song starts out with Angel Moon/Angelina’s distorted alien voice. This voice sounds very similar to the one they used in their song “Cry, Cry, Cry” in the album Everyday Life.

songs.full_title: BrokEn by Coldplay
songs.title: BrokEn

description.plain:
On “BrokEn,” Chris Martin leads a gospel choir in a simple call-and-response structure, backed only by a piano and some finger snaps.

Coldplay dedicated this song to Brian Eno, former producer of the band. In the official release of the lyrics, it says: “For Brian Eno. With love and thanks”. The letters “B” and “E” in the title are capitalized for his initials.

songs.full_title: Brothers & Sisters by Coldplay
songs.title: Brothers & Sisters

description.plain: After forming in 1998, Coldplay met up with local record label Fierce Panda Records after a representative from said label saw them perform at the Camden Falcon in December of that year. Fierce Panda offered to release their debut single, and the band agreed, signing a short record deal. “Easy to Please” and “Only Superstition” we’re the two b-sides on the single.

songs.full_title: Brothers + Sisters (Demo) by Coldplay
songs.title: Brothers + Sisters (Demo)

description.plain:
While pursuing a major record label to sign to, the group’s manager and friend Phil Harvey released a demo tape to various labels that included two songs: “Ode to Deodorant” and “Brothers + Sisters”.

The group would re-work this song in their single release under their first record label Fierce Panda Records, then re-work the song again as a B-side under their second record label Parlophone.

songs.full_title: Champion of the World by Coldplay
songs.title: Champion of the World

description.plain:
“Champion of the World” was released as a tribute to Scott Hutchison, the lead singer of Frightened Rabbit who took his life in May 2018 after struggling with depression. The song was released on November 20th, which would’ve been Scott’s 38th birthday.

This song was inspired by Owl John’s song “Los Angeles, Be Kind.”
